bioghist.p: The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research was founded by John D. Rockefeller, and incorporated in 1901. It was the first institution in the United States devoted solely to biomedical research. In 1955, Rockefeller expanded its mission to include education, admitting its first class of graduate students. It granted its first doctoral degrees in 1959. In 1965, The Rockefeller Institute became The Rockefeller University, broadening its research mandate further. In the early 1960s, new faculty with expertise in physics and mathematics came to Rockefeller. In 1972, the University began its collaboration with Cornell University to offer graduate students an M.D.-Ph.D. program. Later, the Sloan-Kettering Institute became a partner in the program.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of two volumes of Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research Board of Scientific Directors reports from 1931. The reports summarize the work of the various divisions of the institute, including the Departments of the Hospital, Animal Pathology, Experimental Surgery, Chemistry, Chemical Pharmacology, and others. The collection also includes minutes of the Board of Scientific Directors, January and April, 1931. Most of the business recorded in the minutes relates to appointments of staff and to financial matters.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
